revision.text:
{{short description|In general rather than botanical use, plant used for flavoring, food, medicine, or perfume}} {{about|culinary, medicinal, and spiritual herbs|the botanical usage|herbaceous plant|other uses}} [[File:Garden of herbs.jpg|thumb|A variety of herbs are visible in this [[garden]]. Pictured is [[Mentha|mint]], along with some other herbs]]
In general use, '''herbs'''<!--please do not change to the singular; this has caused problems over "an herb" vs. "a herb"--> are plants with savory or aromatic properties that are used for flavoring and [[garnish (food)|garnishing]] food, medicinal purposes, or for fragrances; excluding [[vegetables]] and other plants consumed for [[macronutrients]]. Culinary use typically distinguishes herbs from [[spices]]. ''Herbs'' generally refers to the [[leaf]]y green or [[flower]]ing parts of a plant (either fresh or dried), while ''spices'' are usually dried and produced from other parts of the plant, including [[seed]]s, [[Bark (botany)|bark]], [[root]]s and [[fruit]]s.
Herbs have a variety of uses including culinary, medicinal, and in some cases, spiritual. General usage of the term "herb" differs between culinary herbs and [[medicinal herb]]s; in medicinal or spiritual use, any parts of the plant might be considered as "herbs", including leaves, roots, flowers, seeds, root bark, inner bark (and [[Vascular cambium|cambium]]), [[resin]] and [[pericarp]].
The word "herb" is pronounced {{IPAc-en|h|ÉËr|b}} in [[Commonwealth English]],<ref>{{cite book |title=Cambridge Advanced Learners' Dictionary & Thesaurus |publisher=Cambridge University Press |chapter=Herb |chapter-url=http://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/british/herb?q=herb}}</ref> but {{IPAc-en|ÉËr|b}} is common among [[North American English]] speakers and those from other regions where [[h-dropping]] occurs. In [[botany]], the word "herb" is used as a synonym for "[[herbaceous plant]]". {{Quote box |quote="What is a herb?" "The friend of physicians and the praise of cooks." |author = --[[Alcuin]] and his student [[Charlemagne]]<ref name="Freeman" /> |width = 25% |align = right }}
==Definition== [[File:The Herb Garden - geograph.org.uk - 1629279.jpg|thumb|Herb Garden in Derbyshire, England, originally planted in the 1870s by Lady Louisa Egerton, recreated by the National Trust, largely following the original design.]] In [[botany]], the term herb refers to a [[herbaceous plant]],<ref name="RHS encyclopedia">{{cite book |title=The Royal Horticultural Society encyclopedia of gardening |publisher=Dorling Kindersley |isbn=9781405303538 |edition=2nd |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pulnPwAACAAJ|pages=404,679}}</ref> defined as a small, [[Spermatophyte|seed-bearing plant]] without a woody stem in which all aerial parts (i.e. above ground) die back to the ground at the end of each [[growing season]].<ref name="Allaby2012">{{cite book |last1=Allaby |first1=Michael |title=A Dictionary of Plant Sciences |date=2012 |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=9780191079030 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DB09DAAAQBAJ}}</ref> Usually the term refers to perennials,<ref name="RHS encyclopedia" /> although herbaceous plants can also be [[Annual plant|annual]]s (where the plant dies at the end of the growing season and grows back from seed next year),<ref name="Stuart1989">{{cite book |last1=Stuart |first1=Malcolm |title=The Encyclopedia of herbs and herbalism |date=1989 |publisher=Crescent Books |isbn=978-0517353264 |page=7}}</ref> or [[Biennial plant|biennial]]s.<ref name="RHS encyclopedia" /> This term is in contrast to [[shrub]]s and [[tree]]s which possess a woody stem.<ref name="Allaby2012" /> Shrubs and trees are also defined in terms of size, where shrubs are less than 10 meters tall, and trees may grow over 10 meters.<ref name="Allaby2012" /> The word herbaceous is derived from Latin ''herbÄceus'' meaning "grassy", from ''herba'' "grass, herb".<ref name="OED">{{cite book |title=Oxford dictionary of English. |date=2010 |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=9780199571123 |page=819 |edition=3rd |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=anecAQAAQBAJ}}</ref>
Another sense of the term herb can refer to a much larger range of plants,<ref name="Bown1995">{{cite book |last1=Bown |first1=Deni |title=Encyclopedia of herbs & their uses |date=1995 |publisher=Dorling Kindersley |isbn=978-0751302035 |pages=10,11}}</ref> with culinary, therapeutic or other uses.<ref name="RHS encyclopedia" /> For example, some of the most commonly described herbs such as Sage, Rosemary and Lavender would be excluded from the botanical definition of a herb as they do not die down each year, and they possess woody stems.<ref name="Stuart1989" /> In the wider sense, herbs may be herbaceous perennials but also trees,<ref name="Bown1995" /> subshrubs,<ref name="Bown1995" /> shrubs,<ref name="Bown1995" /> annuals,<ref name="Bown1995" /> [[liana]]s,<ref name="Bown1995" /> [[fern]]s,<ref name="Bown1995" /> [[moss]]es,<ref name="Bown1995" /> [[algae]],<ref name="Bown1995" /> [[lichen]]s,<ref name="Stuart1989" /> and [[fungi]].<ref name="Stuart1989" /> Herbalism can utilize not just stems and leaves but also fruit, roots, bark and gums.<ref name="Stuart1989" /> Therefore one suggested definition of a herb is a plant which is of use to humans,<ref name="Stuart1989" /> although this definition is problematic since it could cover a great many plants that are not commonly described as herbs.
[[ancient Greece|Ancient Greek]] philosopher [[Theophrastus]] divided the plant world into trees, shrubs and herbs.<ref name="Bremness1994">{{cite book |last1=Bremness |first1=Lesley |title=The complete book of herbs |publisher=Viking Studio Books |isbn=9780140238020 |page=8 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VqfnrH-W2kwC}}</ref> Herbs came to be considered in 3 groups, namely [[pot herb]]s (e.g. onions), sweet herbs (e.g. thyme) and salad herbs (e.g. wild celery).<ref name="Stuart1989" /> During the seventeenth century as [[selective breeding]] changed the plants size and flavor away from the wild plant, pot herbs began to be referred to as [[vegetable]]s as they were no longer considered only suitable for the pot.<ref name="Stuart1989" />
== Culinary herbs == [[File:Thyme-Bundle.jpg|thumb|A bundle of [[Thymus (plant)|thyme (''Thymus'')]]]] {{See also|List of culinary herbs and spices}} Culinary herbs are distinguished from [[vegetable]]s in that, like spices, they are used in small amounts and provide [[flavor]] rather than substance to [[food]].<ref name="Small National Research Council Canada 2006">{{cite book |last=Small |first=E. |author2=National Research Council Canada |title=Culinary Herbs |publisher=NRC Research Press |year=2006 |isbn=978-0-660-19073-0 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UL9lpNrx0kwC&pg=PA1 |access-date=9 October 2018 |page=1}}</ref>
Herbs can be [[perennial]]s such as [[thyme]] or [[lavender]], [[Biennial plant|biennials]] such as [[parsley]], or [[Annual plant|annuals]] like [[basil]]. Perennial herbs can be [[shrub]]s such as [[rosemary]], ''Rosmarinus officinalis'', or [[tree]]s such as [[bay laurel]], ''Laurus nobilis'' â this contrasts with [[Herbaceous plant|botanical herbs]], which by definition cannot be woody plants. Some plants are used as both herbs and spices, such as [[dill]] weed and dill seed or [[coriander]] leaves and seeds. There are also some herbs, such as those in the mint family, that are used for both culinary and medicinal purposes.
Emperor [[Charlemagne]] (742-814) compiled a list of 74 different herbs that were to be planted in his gardens. The connection between herbs and health is important already in the European Middle Ages--''[[The Forme of Cury]]'' (that is, "cookery") promotes extensive use of herbs, including in salads, and claims in its preface "the assent and advisement of the masters of physic and philosophy in the King's Court".<ref name="Freeman">{{cite book |title=Herbs for the Medieval Household, for Cooking, Healing and Divers uses |pages=ixâx |first=Margaret B. |last=Freeman |location=New York |publisher=The Metropolitan Museum of Art |year=1943}}</ref>
==Herbal teas== {{main|Herbal tea}} Some herbs can be infused in boiling water to make herbal teas (also termed tisanes).<ref name="RHS encyclopedia" /><ref name="Bown1995" /> Typically the dried leaves, flowers or seeds are used, or fresh herbs are used.<ref name="RHS encyclopedia" /> Herbal teas tend to made from aromatic herbs,<ref name="Bremness1994" /> may not contain [[tannin]]s or [[caffeine]],<ref name="RHS encyclopedia" /> and are not typically mixed with milk.<ref name="Bown1995" /> Common examples include [[chamomile]] tea,<ref name="Bown1995" /> or [[Mint tea]].<ref name="Bremness1994" />
== Medicinal herbs == {{Main|Medicinal plants|Herbalism}} {{see also|List of plants used in herbalism|}} [[File:In Effigiam Nicholai Culpeper Equitis by Richard Gaywood.jpg|thumb|[[Nicholas Culpeper]] was an English [[botany|botanist]], [[Herbalism|herbalist]], [[physician]], and [[astrology|astrologer]].<ref name="ODNB">Patrick Curry: "Culpeper, Nicholas (1616â1654)", ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'' (Oxford, UK: OUP, 2004)</ref> (etching by Richard Gaywood between 1644 and 1662)]]
Herbs were used in [[prehistoric medicine]]. As far back as 5000 BCE, evidence that [[Sumer]]ians used herbs in medicine was inscribed on cuneiform.<ref>{{cite book |first=Ruth D. |last=Wrensch |title=The Essence of Herbs |publisher=University Press of Mississippi |year=1992 |page=9}}</ref> In 162 CE, the physician [[Galen]] was known for concocting complicated herbal remedies that contained up to 100 ingredients.<ref name="Tapsell">{{cite journal |vauthors=Tapsell LC, Hemphill I, Cobiac L, Sullivan DR, Fenech M, Patch CS, Roodenrys S, Keogh JB, Clifton PM, Williams PG, Fazio VA, Inge KE |date=2006 |title=Health benefits of herbs and spices: The past, the present, the future |journal=Medical Journal of Australia |volume=185 |issue=4 |pages=S1âS24 |url=http://ro.uow.edu.au/hbspapers/1397/}}</ref>
Some plants contain [[phytochemical]]s that have effects on the body. There may be some effects when consumed in the small levels that typify culinary "spicing", and some herbs are toxic in larger quantities. For instance, some types of herbal extract, such as the extract of St. John's-wort (''[[Hypericum perforatum]]'') or of kava (''[[Piper methysticum]]'') can be used for medical purposes to relieve depression and stress.<ref>{{cite book |author=Adele G Dawson |title=Herbs, Partners in Life: Healing, Gardening and Cooking with Wild Plants |publisher=Bear & Co. |year=2000 |pages=5â6}}</ref> However, large amounts of these herbs may lead to toxic overload that may involve complications, some of a serious nature, and should be used with caution. Complications can also arise when being taken with some prescription medicines.
Herbs have long been used as the basis of traditional [[Chinese herbal medicine]], with usage dating as far back as the first century [[Common Era|CE]] and far before. In India, the [[Ayurveda]] medicinal system is based on herbs. Medicinal use of herbs in Western cultures has its roots in the [[Hippocratic]] (Greek) elemental healing system, based on a quaternary elemental healing metaphor. Famous herbalist of the Western tradition include [[Avicenna]] (Persian), [[Galen]] (Roman), [[Paracelsus]] (German Swiss), [[Nicholas Culpeper|Culpepper]] (English) and the botanically inclined Eclectic physicians of 19th century/early 20th century America ([[John Milton Scudder]], [[Harvey Wickes Felter]], [[John Uri Lloyd]]). Modern pharmaceuticals had their origins in crude herbal medicines, and to this day, some drugs are still extracted as fractionate/isolate compounds from raw herbs and then purified to meet pharmaceutical standards.
Certain herbs contain psychoactive properties that have been used for both religious and recreational purposes by humans since the early [[Holocene]] era, notably the leaves and extracts of the [[cannabis]] and [[coca]] plants. The leaves of the coca plant have been chewed by people in northern [[Peru]]vian societies for over 8,000 years,<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Dillehay T, Rossen J, Ugent D, Karathanasis A, VÃ¡squez V, Netherly P |year=2010 |title=Early Holocene coca chewing in northern Peru |journal=Antiquity |volume=84 |issue=326 |pages=939â953 |doi=10.1017/S0003598X00067004}}</ref> while the use of cannabis as a psychoactive substance dates back to the first century CE in [[China]] and northern [[Africa]].<ref>{{cite book |author=Ernest Abel |title=Marihuana: The First Twelve Thousand Years |publisher=Springer |location=New York |year=1980 |isbn=978-0-306-40496-2 |url=https://cannabis-truth.yolasite.com/resources/Abel.%20marihuana%20the%20first%20twelve%20thousand%20years.pdf |access-date=2018-07-25}}</ref>
The [[indigenous peoples of Australia]] developed herbal medicine based on plants that were readily available to them. The isolation of the [[Indigenous peoples of Australia|indigenous people]] meant the remedies developed were for far less serious diseases, this was from not contracting western illnesses. Herbs such as [[Mentha australis|river mint]], [[Acacia pycnantha|wattle]] and [[eucalyptus]] were used for coughs, diarrhea, fever and headaches.<ref name="Tapsell" />
== Sacred herbs == {{Main|Sacred herbs}} [[File:Balsamodendron ehrenbergianum00.jpg|thumb|''[[Commiphora gileadensis]]'' (Gilead myrrh)]] Herbs are used in many [[religion]]s. During the monastic era, monks would cultivate herbs alongside vegetables, while others would be set aside in medicinal herb garden for specific purposes.<ref>{{cite book |title=English Herb Garden |first=Guy |last=Cooper |first2=Gordon I. |last2=Taylor |publisher=Random House |year=1986}}</ref> For example, [[myrrh]] (''Commiphora myrrha'') and [[frankincense]] (''Boswellia'' species) in [[Hellenistic religion]], the [[Nine Herbs Charm|nine herbs charm]] in [[Anglo-Saxon paganism]], [[neem]] (''Azadirachta indica'') leaves, [[bael]] (''Aegele marmelos'') leaves, holy basil or ''tulsi'' (''[[Ocimum tenuiflorum]]''), [[turmeric]] or "haldi" (''Curcuma longa''), [[cannabis]] in [[Hinduism]], and [[white sage]] in [[Wicca]]. [[Rastafari movement|Rastafari]] also consider [[Cannabis (drug)|cannabis]] to be a holy plant.
[[Siberia]]n [[shaman]]s also used herbs for spiritual purposes. Plants may be used to induce spiritual experiences for rites of passage, such as [[vision quest]]s in some [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]] cultures. The [[Cherokee]] Native Americans use both [[Salvia apiana|white sage]] and [[Cedar wood|cedar]] for spiritual cleansing and [[Smudge stick|smudging]].
== Herbal cosmetics == Originally there was always doubt in ancient societies, especially in the sceptical medium of western traditions, as to the efficacity of herbal medicines. The use of [[herbal cosmetics]] dates back to around six centuries ago in the European and Western countries. Mixtures and pastes were often concocted to whiten the face. During the 1940s, herbal cosmetics took a turn with the emerging red lipstick color, with every year gaining a more intense red. Herbal cosmetics come in many forms, such as face creams, scrubs, lipstick, natural fragrances, powders, body oils, deodorants and sunscreens. They activate through the epithelium of sebaceous glands to make the skin more supple. Ayurvedic oils are widely used in India, prized for their natural health-giving properties.<ref>{{cite book |first=H. |last=Panda |title=Herbal Cosmetics Handbook |edition=3rd |publisher=Asia-Pacific Business Press |year=2015}}</ref>
One method and perhaps the best, used to extract natural oils from herbs to make lipstick is [[partition chromatography]]. The process involves separation in watery solution, and then the injection of colour under pressure.
==Strewing herbs== {{main|Strewing herb}} Strewing herbs are scattered (strewn) over the floors of dwelling places and other buildings. Such plants usually have fragrant or astringent smells, and many also serve as insecticides (e.g. to repel flees) or disinfectants. For example, [[meadowsweet]] was sometimes strewn across floors in the middle ages because of its sweet smell.<ref name="Bown1995" />
== See also == {{portal|Herbs and spices|Plants}} {{div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[Apothecary]] * [[Herb chopper]] * [[Herb farm]] * [[International Herb Association]] {{div col end}}

{{Infobox writer <!--For more information, see [[:Template:Infobox Writer/doc]].--> | name = Karen Bramson | honorific_prefix = | honorific_suffix = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | pseudonym = | birth_name = Karen Adler | birth_date = {{birth date|1875|08|10}} | birth_place = [[Lyngby-TaarbÃ¦k Municipality|TÃ¥rbÃ¦k]], Denmark | death_date = {{death date and age|1936|01|26|1875|08|10}} | death_place = Paris, France | resting_place = the [[PÃ¨re Lachaise Cemetery]] in Paris | occupation = Author | language = Danish and French | nationality = Danish | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | period = | genre = <!-- or: | genres = --> | subject = <!-- or: | subjects = --> | movement = | notableworks = <!-- or: | notablework = --> | spouse = Dr. Louis Bramson<!-- or: | spouses = --> | partner = <!-- or: | partners = --> | children = Mogens Bramson | relatives = {{plainlist| [[Vera Stanley Alder]] (niece) [[Niels Bohr]] (third cousin) }} | awards = {{plainlist| {{awd|[[LÃ©gion d'honneur]]|1827|Officier|}} {{awd|[[Tagea Brandt Rejselegat]]|1934|}} }} | signature = Karen Bramson signature2.JPG | signature_alt = | years_active = | module = | website = | portaldisp = <!-- "on", "yes", "true", etc; or omit --> }} [[File:PÃ¨re-Lachaise - Division 87 - Columbarium 1062.jpg|thumb|Karen Bramson's grave at the [[PÃ¨re Lachaise Cemetery]] in Paris]] '''Karen Bramson''' (''[[nÃ©e]]'' Adler; born 10 August 1875 in [[Lyngby-TaarbÃ¦k Municipality|TÃ¥rbÃ¦k]], Denmark and died 26 January 1936 in Paris, France) was a Danish author who wrote novels and plays mostly in Danish or French although many of her writings have been translated into English.
Bramson spent her early life in Denmark and her later life in France. She was awarded the [[LÃ©gion d'honneur]] for her work during the First World War and for her contributions to French literature.
==Early life in Denmark== Karen Adler was born on August 10, 1875, in TÃ¥rbÃ¦k, [[Denmark]] with parents Julius Frederick Adler a wealthy cigar merchant in Copenhagen and Dorothea (Thea) Monies<ref name = DBL/> a second cousin of the physicist [[Niels Bohr]].<ref name = Brenner/> She had several siblings, one of which was her elder brother, David Julius Adler. Karen was apparently a better writer than David, because she would sometimes write David Adler's school essays for him. Karen Adler started writing plays at the age of 12 and at 14, had a play in two acts - "Veninder" (Girlfriends) and "I pension for unge piger" (In a boarding house for young girls) - accepted at the [[Folketeatret, Copenhagen|Folketeatret]] (People's Theatre) in Copenhagen for a fee of 200 Danish Kroner.<ref name = Holst>{{Cite web | last = Holst | first = Holger Christian | date = 4 May 2000 | url = http://sites.univ-provence.fr/~wperse/holst.htm | title = Le jeune Alexis Leger/Saint-John Perse vu par Karen Bramson | trans-title = Young Alexis Leger/Saint-John Perse as seen by Karen Bramson | website = Colloque international PostÃ©ritÃ©s de Saint-John Perse | language = French, English | publisher = Aix Marseilles University | access-date = 12 May 2015}}</ref> She had insisted that she should remain anonymous, but the theatre director could not resist giving her name to the local newspaper. Karen hurriedly withdrew her play and refunded the fee to avoid scandal and her father's wrath, for in 1890s Copenhagen, it was unheard of for a young lady of her class to attract such publicity and get paid for writing a play.<ref name = KVInfo>{{cite web | url= http://www.kvinfo.dk/side/597/bio/216/origin/170/|title= Karen Bramson (1875 - 1936)|last1= Jensen |first1= Marianne Majgaard |date= 2003 |publisher=KVINFO |website= [[Dansk kvindebiografisk leksikon]] (Danish women's autobiographical library) |language = Danish |access-date= 6 June 2015}}</ref> In 1893, at the age of 17, Karen Adler married Louis Bramson (b. 1861 - d 1952). Louis, like Karen, came from a relatively prosperous Danish family, was a doctor and was 15 years older than Karen.<ref name = DBL/> In 1895 they had a son, Mogens Bramson. Karen Bramson continued to write and made her dÃ©but in print with the two plays "Den unge Frue. Mands Vilje" (The young lady - Man's Will) published in 1900 and performed in 1907<ref name = DBH/> at the People's Theatre in Copenahgen.
In 1904, Karen and Louis Bramson built a country mansion which they called SolgÃ¥rden (Sun Yard) near the sea in StrÃ¸by Egede, [[Stevns Municipality]] just south of Copenhagen.<ref>{{Cite web |date = 2015 | url = http://www.visitdenmark.co.uk/en-gb/denmark/solgardsparken-in-stroeby-egede-gdk619900 | title = Solgardsparken in Stroeby Egede | website = Visit Denmark | publisher = Danish Tourist Office | access-date = 20 May 2015}}</ref> They invited artists from different parts of Europe and held plays on a stage they had built there.<ref>{{Cite web | date = 2015 | url = http://www.solgaardsparken.dk/default.asp?pageID=2 | title = SolgÃ¥rdsparken, StrÃ¸by Egede, Historiske billeder | trans-title = Solgards park, Stroby Egede, Historic images | language = Danish | publisher = Solgard Park, StrÃ¸by Egede | access-date = 20 May 2015}}</ref> King [[Frederick VIII of Denmark]] is said to have stayed there in 1911 and, in commemoration, is said to have presented Karen with four marble statues of eagles which were placed on the corners of a tower in the building.<ref>{{Cite web | publication-date = April 2008 | url= http://www.bruun-rasmussen.dk/vfs/catalogues/786/786_mob-porc | publisher = Bruun Rasmussen Antiques | publication-place = Copenhagen, Denmark | title = Auction 786; The Departments of Decorative Art | page = 7 | access-date = 20 May 2015}}</ref><ref name = Solgarden>{{Cite web | date = 2015 | url = http://www.solgaardsparken.dk/default.asp?pageID=1 | title = Historien bag SolgÃ¥rdsparken | trans-title = The History of Solgards Park | language = Danish | publisher = Solgard Park, StrÃ¸by Egede |access-date = 20 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | url = http://historiskatlas.dk/Solg%C3%A5rdsparken_(6682) | title = SolgÃ¥rdsparken | trans-title = Solgards park | publisher = Historical atlas | language = Danish | access-date = 20 May 2015}}</ref>
In 1912, Karen Bramson was elected a councillor of [[Copenhagen Municipality]] but declined, preferring to concentrate on writing.<ref name = Suffragette>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= Suffragette Refuses Office and Gains Literary Honors. Mmme Bronson Expected to Raise Women's Standards|url= https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=950&dat=19120316&id=2IQLAAAAIBAJ&sjid=6lMDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5637,553781&hl=en|newspaper= The Evening Independent|location= St. Petersburg, Florida, USA|date= 16 March 1912|access-date= 8 June 2015}}</ref> In 1914, Karen Bramson left Denmark and moved to France in a personal protest against Denmark remaining neutral during the [[World War I]]. She was to spend the rest of her life in France.<ref name = Solgarden/>
==Literary career in France== After Karen Bramson settled permanently in Paris, France at the beginning of the First World War, she wrote mostly in French. During the war, she was attached to the press department of the French [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs]], which tried to create international awareness of the country's situation. Bramson was an enthusiastic writer and propagandist for the French cause and tried to help the plight of French prisoners of war in Germany.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= Says Germany Spreads Phtsisis Among Prisoners; Tuberculous Victims Deliberately Mixed with Others, Mme. Bramson Alleges.|url= https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9907E2D91439E233A25757C2A96F9C946796D6CF|newspaper= The New York Times|location= New York, USA|date= 24 September 1916|access-date= 6 June 2015}}</ref><ref name = Lachaise>{{Cite web | date = 16 March 2008 | url= http://www.appl-lachaise.net/appl/article.php3?id_article=1602 | title = Bramson Karen (1875-1936) | language = French | publisher = Amis et PassionÃ©s du PÃ¨re-Lachese; Ãcrivains - PoÃ¨tes - LittÃ©rateurs; 87eme division (Columbarium) | access-date = 21 May 2015}}</ref> She was awarded the rank of Chevalier in the [[LÃ©gion d'honneur]] in 1917 for the work she did during the First World War.<ref name = DBL/>
After the war, her greatest triumph was the performance in 1923 of her play "Le Professeur Klenow" at the [[Theatre de l'Odeon]] in Paris<ref>(2015) [http://www.theatre-odeon.eu/en/p RÃ©pertoire] OdÃ©on ThÃ©Ã¢tre de l'Europe, Paris, Retrieved 3 June 2015</ref> with actor [[Poul Reumert]] in the lead role.<ref name = RegieTheatrale>{{cite web |url=http://www.regietheatrale.com/index/index/mises_en_scene/MeS_exemples.php|title = Les RelevÃ©s de mises en scÃ¨nes Ã©crites| trans-title = List of written productions|language = French|date= 23 October 2008 |publisher= collections de l'Association de la RÃ©gie ThÃ©Ã¢trale|access-date= 6 June 2015}}</ref> Later in 1923 there was a reworked version of her 1902 play, "Den StÃ¦rkeste" (The Strongest), as guest performance at the Royal Theatre in Copenhagen. Shortly before, at the same theatre, her play "De evige Fjender" (The Eternal Enemies) with Reumert and the actress [[Bodil Ipsen]] in the lead roles met with limited success. However, in June 1924 the same play translated into English with the title "Tigercats" and starring [[Edith Evans]],<ref>{{cite book|last1=Worsley|first1=Luccy|title=The Times Great Women's Lives: A Celebration in Obituaries|date=15 September 2014|publisher=The History Press|location=United Kingdom|isbn=9780750962346|chapter=Dame Edith Evans}}</ref> [[Nicholas Hannen (actor)|Nicholas Hannen]]<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=|title=Obituary: Fru Karen Bramson|last=|first=|date=1936-01-28|newspaper=The Times|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|work=|page=13|via=}}</ref> and [[Robert Loraine]]<ref>{{cite book|last1=Senelick|first1=Laurence|title=Theatre Arts on Acting|date=September 2013|publisher=Routledge|location=United Kingdom|isbn=9781134723751|page=316}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Liggera|first1=Lanayre D.|title=The Life of Robert Loraine: The Stage, the Sky, and George Bernard Shaw|date=August 2013|publisher=University of Delaware Press|location=USA|isbn=9781611494594|page=181}}</ref> was performed at the [[Garrick Theatre]] and then the [[Royal Strand Theatre]] in London, where it was much more successful and ran for 116 performances.<ref name = LondonStage>{{cite book | first = J.P. | last = Wearing | title = The London Stage 1920-1929: A Calendar of Productions, Performers, and Personnel |edition=2nd | publisher = Rowman & Littlefield Education|location = London, UK| date = 2014 | isbn = 978-0810893016 | oclc = 863695327|page = 313 }}</ref> "Tigercats", directed by [[David Belasco]] also ran for 48 performances in the [[Belasco Theatre]] on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] in New York with [[Katharine Cornell]]<ref>{{cite book|last1=Sicherman|first1=Barbara|last2=Green|first2=Carol Hurd|title=Notable American Women: A Biographical Dictionary, Volume 4: The Modern Period|date=January 1986|publisher=Harvard University Press|location=USA|isbn=9780674627338|page=168}}</ref> and Lorraine in the lead roles.<ref name = TigerCats>{{cite web |url= http://www.ibdb.com/production.php?id=9606 |title= Tiger Cats|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= 2015 |publisher= The Internet Broadway Database|access-date= 6 June 2015}}</ref> Other plays by Karen Bramson performed in England about this time were "Medusa", "The Godless" ([[Wyndham's Theatre|Wyndhams theatre]] December 1925), "The Enchantress" (The [[Garrick Theatre]] April 1926), "The Man they Buriedâ¦" (The [[Ambassadors Theatre (London)|Ambassadors Theatre]] June 1928) and "The Tower of Babel" (Venturers Society July 1929).<ref name=":0" /><ref name = LondonStage/><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.kent.ac.uk/library/specialcollections/theatre/r.php/36461/show.html|title= Theatre collections: Medusa (La Femme Fatale) | last1= Adller |first1= F. |date= 8 March 1926 |website= University of Kent, UK, Special Collections|publisher= the Pleasure Gardens Theatre, Folkstone, Kent, England|access-date= 10 June 2015}}</ref> "Tigercats" was revived at the [[Royalty Theatre|Royalty theatre]] in May 1931 with Edith Evans and Robert Lorraine in the same roles as before.<ref name=":0" /> In 1925 she was the first foreign female author to have a play accepted at the [[ComÃ©die-FranÃ§aise]] in Paris.<ref name = Loiret>{{cite news |date= 28 January 1936|title= Mort de l 'Ã©crivain danois Mme Karen-Bramson|trans-title= Death of the Danish author Mrs Karen Bramson|language= French|newspaper= Journal du Loiret|page= 1 }}</ref> Other plays of hers performed in Paris included "Puissance de Roi" ([[OdÃ©on-ThÃ©Ã¢tre de l'Europe|OdÃ©on Theatre]]), "Des yeux qui s'ouvrent" (also at the OdÃ©on) and "Bonheur" (Ambassadeurs theatre).<ref name=":0" /> She was made an Officier in the LÃ©gion d'honneur in 1927 because of her contributions to French literature and plays.<ref name = Burials>{{cite web |url= http://gravsted.dk/person.php?navn=karenbramson|title= Karen Bramson, Dansk forfatter |language= Danish | trans-title = Karen Bramson, Danish author | last1= Adller |first1= F. |date= 2013 |website= |publisher= Kendtes gravsted (Celebrity burials) |access-date= 6 June 2015}}</ref> In 1934 she also received the [[Tagea Brandt Rejselegat]] Danish award. Karen Bramson was known in fashionable circles in Paris had a reputation for being a brilliant hostess inviting artists, diplomats and politicians to receptions in her house. For example, she was friends with the poet and diplomat [[Saint-John Perse]] (who was awarded the [[Nobel Prize for Literature]]), the diplomat [[Philippe Berthelot]], his wife HÃ©lÃ¨ne<ref name = Holst/> and the French politician [[Louis Barthou]].<ref name = Figaro>{{cite news |date= 1 February 1936|title= NÃ©crologie - Les obsÃ¨ques du Mme Karen Bramson|trans-title= Obituary - Funeral of Mrs Karen Bramson|language= French|newspaper= Le Figaro|location= Paris, France}}</ref> Despite her versatile talents, her literary ambitions and a life in the media spotlight, her inner personality was mostly hidden. She disliked giving interviews and was reticent about divulging details of her personal life.<ref name = KVInfo/>
==Final years and Death== In her final years she retired from public life and studied spiritualism. She had always loved a cosmopolitan life and travelled throughout Europe staying in various hotels before dying in 1936 of a [[cerebral hemorrhage]]<ref name = DundeeTelegraph>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= The death has occurred in Paris from cerebral haemorrhage of Madame Karen- Bramson, the Danish writer |newspaper= The Dundee Evening Telegraph|location= Angus, Scotland|date= 28 January 1936 |page = 6 }}</ref> in a hotel room in Paris.<ref name=LePetitDauphinois>{{cite news |date= 28 January 1936 |title= Mme Karen Bramson grand Ã©crivain danois est morte Ã Paris|trans-title= Mrs Karen Bramson, the great Danish author has died in Paris |url= http://www.memoireetactualite.org/presse/38PETITDAUPH/PDF/1936/38PETITDAUPH-19360128-P-0001.pdf|language= French|newspaper= Le Petit Dauphinois|location= Grenoble, France|access-date= 6 June 2015}}</ref> Her ashes were buried at the PÃ¨re Lachaise cemetery in Paris.<ref name = Beyern >{{cite book | first = Bertrand | last = Beyern | title = Guide des tombes d'hommes cÃ©lÃ¨bres | trans-title = Guide to the graves of famous men | publisher = Le Cherche Midi| date = 2011 | isbn = 978-2749121697 }}</ref>
==Reception and legacy== Her first plays ("The Young Lady", "Man's Will" in 1900 and "Mothers" in 1901 ) have been described as focussing on the oppression women suffer in marriage and she often explored themes of interpersonal relationships and the battle of the sexes. Deadly love and female masochist tendencies have also been mentioned by reviewers.<ref name = DBL/> One newspaper review of her play "Tiger Cats" noted the London audience "...consisting mainly of middle-aged, unmarried women cheered wildly these scenes of sadism."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Wearing|first1=J. P.|title=The London Stage 1920-1929: A Calendar of Productions, Performers, and Personnel|date=2014|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|location=Plymouth, UK|isbn=978-0-8108-9301-6|page=308}}</ref> She has also been described as a [[feminist]]<ref name = Suffragette/> and a writer of [[science fiction]] in the near future.<ref>{{Cite web | date = 25 October 2014 | url = http://www.sf-encyclopedia.com/entry/bramson_karen | title = Bramson, Karen | publisher = The Encyclopedia of Science Fiction |access-date = 3 June 2015}}</ref> In 1932 she was regarded by some critics as "the most significant figure in Nordic literature since [[Henrik Ibsen|Ibsen]]s time."<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= News and Views of Interest to Women in Professional and Domestic Fields - In Nordic Literature|url= http://fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2018/New%20York%20NY%20Sun/New%20York%20NY%20Sun%201932/New%20York%20NY%20Sun%201932%20-%201588.pdf |newspaper= The New York Sun|location= |date= 11 February 1932|access-date= 6 June 2015}}</ref> The opinion of [[The Times]] obituary in January 1936 was that she was perhaps more successful as a novelist than a playwright<ref name=":0" /> - in particular for her books "Parmi les hommes" (a vast fresco of Europe before and after World War 1 including the curious character of Lenin), "Un seul homme" (an analysis of an English revolutionary), "Nous les barbares" (a study of middle-class life ofher day) and "Star" (the story of a young girl and Hollywood).<ref name=":0" />
==Bramson's family== Karen Bramson and her husband Louis Bramson had one son Mogens Louis Bramson<ref name = Mogens/> After 1914, she lived apart from her husband, but had a friendly relationship with him throughout her life. She adored her son Mogens, who was a pilot<ref name = Mogens>Mulder, Rob J.M., (24 November 2011) [http://www.europeanairlines.no/skywriting-%E2%80%93-mr-bramson-above-christiania/ Skywriting - Mr. Bramson above Christiana (Oslo)] European Airlines, reprinted from original article in "Flight" magazine 21 June 1923, Retrieved 13 May 2015</ref> and aviation engineering consultant. Mogens Bramson lived much of his life in England and played a crucial role in helping [[Frank Whittle]] develop the world's first [[jet engine]].<ref>{{Cite journal |last= Meher-Homji|first= Cyrus B. |date= 2002|title= Enabling the Turbojet Revolution â The Bramson Report|url= http://files.asme.org/IGTI/News/25224.pdf |journal= |publisher= American Society of Mechanical Engineers|volume= 42|issue= 1|pages= 16â20|access-date=16 July 2015}}</ref> Later in his life Mogens moved to California, USA where he invented a [[heart lung machine]].<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= the Bramson lung|newspaper= Independent|location= Long Beach, California|date= 23 August 1972 |page =27 |url= https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/25984202/ |subscription=yes |access-date= 16 July 2015}} "..The instrument, which assists the heart and lungs, is known as the Bramson lung, named for its designer, Mogens L. Bramson, an engineer. Although the device warms blood and enriches it with oxygen, 50 to 60 per cent of the patient's blood can still be pumped by the natural heart. The patient thus retains his natural pulse. Dr. J. Donald Hill of Presbyterian Hospital of Pacific Medical Center, San Francisco, says the Bramson lung buys time for damaged lungs to heal. Standard heart-lung machines may lead to blood damage when used for longer than six hours..."</ref> One source says Karen Bramson's older sister Olga married the Russian Prince Vladimir Orloff.<ref name = Brenner>{{cite book | first = Otto | last = Brenner| title = Leksikon over danske familier | trans-title = Encyclopaedia of Danish families | language = Danish | publisher = The Personal Institute |location = Copenhagen, Denmark | date = 1927 | asin = | isbn = | oclc = 482088191 | access-date = }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= Niece of Prince and Princess|newspaper= Western Mail and South Wales News|location= Cardiff, Wales|date= 1 December 1938 }}</ref> Karen's brother David Julius Adler was the father of the author and painter [[Vera Stanley Alder]].

Manâs Will; two plays | language = Danish | publisher = To skuespil, Gyldendalske boghandels forlag (F. Hegel & sÃ¸n)|location = Copenhagen, Denmark| date = 1900| asin = B000WHFDTE| oclc = 493768937}}</ref>) *''MÃ¸dre'' (Mothers; 1901, play<ref name = Madre>{{cite book | first = Karen | last = Bramson | title = MÃ¸dre skuespil i tre akter | trans-title = Mothers; Play in three acts | language = Danish | publisher = Gyldendal|location = Copenhagen, Denmark | date = 1901| asin = B000WHGO4M | oclc = 248764352}}</ref> in Danish also translated into German<ref name = Mutter>{{cite book | first = Karen | last = Bramson | title = Mutter : Schauspiel | trans-title = Mother : Play| language = German | translator = Otto Hamburger| publisher = NÃ¼rnberg : Frankfurter |location = | date = c. 1901| oclc = 248764352}}</ref>) *''Den StÃ¦rkeste'' (The Strongest; 1902, play in Danish also translated into English as ''Professor Klenov'',<ref name = IBDStrong>{{cite web | date = 2015 |url = http://ibdb.com/production.php?id=9482 |title = The Strong |publisher = Internet Broadway Database |access-date = 13 May 2015}}</ref> into French<ref name = RegieTheatrale/><ref>{{cite web |last = Lavauzelle | first = Jacky | date = 17 February 2015 | url = http://artgitato.com/karen-bramson-le-professeur-klenow-la-laideur-de-lamour/ | title = Karen Bramson â Le Professeur Klenow : La laideur de lâamour | publisher = Artgitato | language = French | trans-title = Karen Bramson - Professor Klenow - the ugliness of love |access-date = 26 May 2015}}</ref> and Arabic.<ref>{{cite book | first = Karen | last = Bramson | title = al-UstÄdh KlinÅ«v | trans-title = Professor Klenov| language = Arabic | translator = á¹¢alÄá¸¥ al-DÄ«n KÄmil | oclc = 30987207}}</ref>) *''Det lyriska versdramat Berengaria, Dronning af Danmark'' (Berengaria, Queen of Denmark, in lyrical verse; {{Infobox lake | name = Lake Pancharevo | image = PancharevoLake1.JPG | caption = View from the east bank, with the [[Vitosha Mountains]] in the background | image_bathymetry = | caption_bathymetry = | location = | coords = {{coord|42|36|00|N|23|24|28|E|source:bgwiki_type:waterbody_region:BG|display=inline,title}} | type = [[reservoir]] | inflow = | outflow = | catchment = | basin_countries = Bulgaria | length = {{convert|3|km|abbr=on}} | width = {{convert|700|m|abbr=on}} | area = | depth = | max-depth = {{convert|30|m|abbr=on}} | volume = {{convert|6.4|hm3|acre.ft|abbr=on}} | residence_time = | shore = | elevation = {{convert|600|m|abbr=on}} | frozen = | islands = | cities = }} '''Lake Pancharevo''' (ÐÐ°Ð½ÑÐ°ÑÐµÐ²ÑÐºÐ¾ ÐµÐ·ÐµÑÐ¾, ''Pancharevsko ezero'' or Ð¯Ð·Ð¾Ð²Ð¸Ñ ÐÐ°Ð½ÑÐ°ÑÐµÐ²Ð¾, ''Pancharevo Reservoir'') is an [[artificial lake]] in western [[Bulgaria]], at the end of the [[Pancharevo Gorge]] of the [[Iskar River]], located at 600 m above sea level between the [[Vitosha]] and [[Lozenska]] mountains. It is 3 km long and up to 700 m wide, reaching a depth of 30 m, and is situated 12 km southeast of the capital city of [[Sofia]], where the [[Vitoshka Bistritsa]] flows into the [[Iskar (river)|Iskar]]. The villages of [[Pancharevo]] and [[Kokalyane]] and the Pancharevo [[mineral spring]]s lies on the lake's western shore, while at the southern end of the lake there is a [[Hydroelectricity|hydroelectric]] power station. Sports centres and catering establishments have been constructed around the lake, making it a favoured outing location for the residents of Sofia. Further upstream in the gorge there are two additional artificial lakes: the [[Pasarel Reservoir]] and the [[Iskar Reservoir]].
The lake was created in 1956 in connection with the construction of Hydrohub "Iskar", as a drinking, irrigation and energy source for the Sofia Agglomeration.
The (Sredets) National Rowing Base is located on the shore of Lake Pancharevo. Built in 1968, the rowing base is the first modern facility in [[Bulgaria]], specializing in conducting training and competitions in rowing events. In 1977 it hosted the World Cup canoe in the capital, and in 1981, the World Championships for young people in water sports. Over the years, it has been host to several world championships, national and international rowing regattas, and the European Triathlon Championships.
[[File:Sredets Rowing base.jpg|thumb|Sredets National Rowing base on the shore of Lake Pancharevo, Sofia]]
[[File:PancharevoLake2.JPG|thumb|none|Lake Pancharevo from the dam]][[File:Rowing regatta on Pancharevo Lake.png|thumb|none|Rowing regatta on Lake Pancharevo]]

revision.text:
'''Local boards''' or '''local boards of health''' were local authorities in urban areas of [[England and Wales]] from 1848 to 1894. They were formed in response to [[cholera]] epidemics and were given powers to control sewers, clean the streets, regulate environmental health risks including [[slaughterhouses]] and ensure the proper supply of water to their districts. Local boards were eventually merged with the corporations of [[municipal borough]]s in 1873, or became [[urban district (Great Britain and Ireland)|urban district]]s in 1894.
==Pre-Public Health Act 1848== {{see|Improvement commissioners}}
==Public Health Act 1848== The first local boards were created under the '''Public Health Act 1848''' (11 & 12 Vict. c.63). The aim of the act was to improve the sanitary condition of towns and populous places in England and Wales by placing: the supply of water; sewerage; drainage; cleansing; paving, and environmental health regulation under a single local body. The act could be applied to any place in England and Wales except the [[City of London]] and some other areas in the [[County of London|Metropolis]] already under the control of [[Metropolitan Commission of Sewers|sewer commissioners]].
The Act was passed by the [[Liberal Party (UK)|Liberal]] [[First Russell ministry|government]] of [[John Russell, 1st Earl Russell|Lord John Russell]], in response to the urging of [[Edwin Chadwick]]. This was supported by reports, from local branches of the [[Health of Towns Association]] (formed in 1844), of poor and insanitary conditions in many UK cities.<ref name=Ashton-Ubido>{{cite journal|last=Ashton |first=John |author2=Ubido, Janet |title=The Healthy City and the Ecological Idea |journal=Journal of the Society for the Social History of Medicine |year=1991 |volume=4 |issue=1 |pages=173â181 |url=http://www.johnrashton.securemachines.co.uk/documentbank/the%20healthy%20city%20and%20the%20ecological%20idea.pdf |accessdate=8 July 2013 |doi=10.1093/shm/4.1.173 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131224102422/http://www.johnrashton.securemachines.co.uk/documentbank/the%20healthy%20city%20and%20the%20ecological%20idea.pdf |archivedate=24 December 2013 |df= }}</ref>
===General Board of Health=== The act created a '''General Board of Health''' as a central authority to administer the act. There were three commissioners:- the president of the board being the First Commissioner of Her Majesty's Woods and Forests, Land Revenues, Works and Buildings, the other two members being appointed by warrant. The board was originally to be dissolved after five years, but acts of parliament were passed annually allowing for its continuation. Chadwick was appointed a Commissioner, and the Board was strongly associated with him. In 1852, Edward Gotto was employed to carry out the national General Board of Health Survey.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Thorne |first=Alice |title=An Archaeological Desk-Based Assessment and Walkover Survey of Land at The Pentagon Centre, Chatham |year=Oct 2006 |url=http://archaeologyse.co.uk/ReportLibrary/2006/2006-2565-Pentagon-Centre-Chatham-DBA.pdf |page=19 |accessdate=1 February 2014 |publisher=archaeologyse.co.uk }}</ref>
The board finally ceased to exist on 1 September 1858.
===Forming a local board of health=== Local boards could be formed in two ways: * By a petition of one tenth of the inhabitants rated to [[poor law|relief of the poor]] in any city, town, borough (municipal or parliamentary), parish or place with a defined boundary not having less than 30 such qualified ratepayers. * By the General Board if the death rate exceeded twenty-three in a thousand in any place.
In the latter case a superintending inspector appointed by the General Board would hold an inquiry into the sewerage, drainage, supply of water, state of burial grounds and other matters relating to the sanitary condition of the town, and where necessary define boundaries for the district of the local board.
Where the boundaries of a proposed local board's district were the same as an existing local unit, the act was applied by [[Order in Council]]. Where a new district was created this was done by provisional order of the General Board, confirmed by parliament.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://spartacus-educational.com/PHchadwick.htm|title=Edwin Chadwick|author=|date=|website=spartacus-educational.com}}</ref>
===Membership of a local board=== Members of local boards were either: * Selected by the corporations of [[municipal borough]]s * Elected by owners of property and by rate payers
Where a local board district coincided with a borough, or was entirely within a borough's limits, all the members were selected by the corporation. Where a district was entirely outside a municipality, all the members were elected. In districts which were partly in and partly outside a borough the board had a mixture of selected and elected members. Selected members did not have to be members of the corporation. Borough mayors were ''ex officio'' board members.
Those entitled to elect board members could have multiple votes depending on how much property they owned. This ranged from one vote for owners of property worth less than fifty pounds, to six votes for those holding more than 250 pounds of property. It followed that board members were generally wealthy property owners or members of the professions.
===Powers of a local board=== The powers and duties of a local board of health were enumerated in the act: * Employees: A local board of health was allowed to appoint a number of employees including a surveyor, a clerk, a treasurer and an officer of health (who had to be a qualified doctor). It was compulsory for the Board to appoint an inspector of nuisances (sanitary inspector) to investigate complaints and take action against 'nuisances' (nuisances was a very broad concept encompassing a wide range of environmental public health problems: such as unsanitary dwellings, accumulations of refuse and sewage, smoke dust and smells and industrial emissions, polluted water, noise, adulterated food, slaughterhouse issues etc.). * Sewers: The local board took over ownership of all public sewers in its district. Where private sewers operated for profit, the local board could purchase them. * Street cleansing: The local board was required to clean the streets in its district, removing dust, ashes, rubbish, filth, dung and soil. * Public lavatories: The local board could provide "public necessities" (as the act called them). * Slaughterhouses: The local board was to regulate slaughterhouses, and was allowed to provide such facilities itself. * Street paving: The local board took over the public streets in the district, and could also require that private streets be paved. * Pleasure grounds: The local boards were allowed to provide and lay out pleasure grounds. * Water Supply: The local board was allowed to supply water, but only if a private company could not provide the service. * Burials: The local board was allowed to provide houses for the reception of the dead prior to burial. They could also apply to the General Board to have an existing graveyard closed. * Land: The local board could purchase land.
==Local Government Act 1858== The 1848 Act was replaced by the '''Local Government Act 1858''' (21 & 22 Vict. c. 98). The act came into force in all existing local board of health districts on 1 September 1858. The act made some changes to the procedure for constituting a local board and gave them some additional powers. There was also a change in nomenclature: the authorities created by the 1858 act were simply entitled "local boards" and their areas as "local government districts".
===The Local Government Act Office and the Local Government Board=== When the General Board of Health was abolished in 1858 its responsibilities in respect of local government passed to the [[Home Secretary|Secretary of State of the Home Department]], in whose department a '''Local Government Act Office''' was formed to administer the local boards. In 1871 a separate agency was again formed entitled the [[Local Government Board]], with a President who was frequently a [[Cabinet of the United Kingdom|Cabinet]] member. The Local Government Board also took over the duties of the [[Poor Law Board]].
===Constituting local boards=== The procedure for adopting the act and constituting a local board was laid out in sections 12 â 17 of the act, and was similar to that in the 1848 act.
Changes made included: * [[Improvement commissioners]] could adopt the act for their district, the board of commissioners becoming in addition the local board. * Petitions from ten per cent of the ratepayers of places other than those with a "known or defined boundary" to adopt the act were now made to the Secretary of State. If one in twenty ratepayers objected to the formation of a local board they now had the [[right to petition]] against it. * The power to create a local board where there was excess mortality was abolished.
The method of electing members of the board remained the same, although existing or new boards could now be divided into wards.
===Additional powers=== The [[Town Police Clauses Act 1847]] had included model clauses for the government of towns which could be adopted in all or in part by existing borough corporations, local boards of health or improvement commissioners. The application of these was very uneven, so they were incorporated into the 1858 act, all local boards gaining these powers.
Areas covered by the clauses were: * Removal of obstructions and nuisances in the street * Fires and fire prevention * Provision and control of places of public resort * Regulation of [[hackney carriages]] * Provision of public bathing houses * Naming streets and numbering houses * Improving the line of streets * Removal of ruinous or dangerous buildings * Provision of public clocks
The local board also took over any lamps, lamp posts and gas posts provided by the [[Lighting and Watching Act 1833]], and was given a new power to provide a market place where one was required or inadequate.
==Number of local boards== The number of local boards peaked at 721 in 1873. In that year the [[Public Health Act 1872]] merged local boards into municipal boroughs and improvement commissioners where they shared the same district. 419 of the local boards had been formed under the '''Public Health Act 1848''', the remaining 302 under the '''Local Government Act 1858'''.
The number of local boards was inflated in 1862â63, as communities adopted the act in order to avoid being grouped into [[highway district]]s under the [[Highways Act 1862]]. Many of these local government districts had a population of fewer than 500, and several fewer than 100. Further legislation was passed in 1863 to limit the population of a new local government district to 3,000 or more. Some of these small authorities survived as [[urban district (Great Britain and Ireland)|urban district]]s until the [[Local Government Act 1929|county review orders]] of the 1930s.
==Sanitary districts and urban districts== The [[Public Health Act 1875]] designated local government districts as [[sanitary district|urban sanitary districts]], with the local board becoming the urban sanitary authority. The titles of the district and board did not change however, the local board assuming extra duties as a sanitary authority.
Local boards and local government districts were finally abolished by the [[Local Government Act 1894]], when all urban sanitary districts became [[urban district (Great Britain and Ireland)|urban district]]s. A new urban district council was to govern the district. The new council was to be directly elected by all those entitled to voted in parliamentary elections, replacing the weighted property voting system used for local boards.
==See also== *[[List of Acts of Parliament of the United Kingdom Parliament, 1840-1859]] *[[Local boards formed in England and Wales 1848â94]]
==Sources== * Public Health Act 1848 * Local Government Act 1858 * Local Government Act 1894
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
{{District status in the United Kingdom}} {{UK legislation}}

revision.text:
In 1982, '''The Midwives Alliance of North America (MANA)''' was established as a professional organization for [[midwives]]. Its stated goal is to unify and strengthen the profession of midwifery, thereby improving the quality of health care for women, babies, and communities.<ref>{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | vauthors = | title = Home page | work = | publisher =Midwives Alliance of North America | date = | url = http://www.mana.org | format = | doi = | accessdate = 10 May 2012}}</ref>
== Stated goals == The organization states that its goals are:
* To expand communication and support among North American midwives * To form an identifiable and cohesive organization representing the profession of midwifery on a regional, national, and international basis. * To promote guidelines for the education of midwives and to assist in the development of midwifery education programs * To promote research in the field of midwifery as a quality health care option * To promote and support a woman's right to choose her care provider and place of birth * To promote public education and midwifery advocacy
== Membership == MANA membership includes midwives and student midwives, other healthcare providers, and families.
Over one-third of MANA's member midwives are certified professional midwives (CPMs),<ref>{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | vauthors = | title = Issue brief: Certified Professional Midwives in the United States | work = | publisher =North American Registry of Midwives, Midwifery Education Accreditation Council, National Association of Certified Professional Midwives, Midwives Alliance of North America | date =June 2008 | url = http://mana.org/pdfs/CPMIssueBrief.pdf | format = | doi = | accessdate = 10 May 2012}}</ref> the remainder are [[nurse midwife|certified nurse midwives]], certified midwives, state-licensed midwives, traditional midwives, and student/apprentice midwives.
==See also== * [[Childbirth]] * [[Doula]] * [[Midwife]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.mana.org Midwives Alliance of North America (MANA)] * [http://www.narm.org North American Registry of Midwives (NARM)] * [http://www.midwife.org American College of Nurse-Midwives (ACNM)] * [http://asteria.fivecolleges.edu/findaids/sophiasmith/mnsss102_main.html Archival records of the Midwives' Alliance of North America, 1973-1999], at Smith College
[[Category:Midwifery organizations]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1982]] [[Category:1982 establishments in the United States]]

The '''National Health Research Institutes''' ('''NHRI'''; {{zh|c=åå®¶è¡çç ç©¶é¢|p=GuÃ³jiÄ WÃ¨ishÄng YÃ¡njiÃ¹yuÃ n}}) in [[Zhunan, Miaoli|Zhunan Township]], [[Miaoli County]], [[Taiwan]], is a [[non-profit foundation]] dedicated to [[medical research]] and improved [[healthcare in Taiwan]]. Established by the [[Taiwan]] government in 1995, NHRI is under the supervision of the [[Ministry of Health and Welfare (Republic of China)|Ministry of Health and Welfare]].
==Organisation== NHRI currently has 11 research units:

revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:National Safety Month}} '''National Safety Month (NSM)''' is an annual month-long observance in the [[United States]] each June. [[File:National Safety Month Badget.png|thumb|Official Badge of National Safety Month 2018]] During National Safety Month, individuals and organizations participate by making efforts to reduce the leading causes of unintentional injury and death at [https://www.osha.gov/oshstats/commonstats.html work]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.osha.gov/oshstats/commonstats.html|title=Commonly Used Statistics {{!}} Occupational Safety and Health Administration|website=www.osha.gov|language=en-us|access-date=2018-05-10}}</ref>, on the [http://www.iihs.org/iihs/topics/t/general-statistics/fatalityfacts/state-by-state-overview road]<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.iihs.org/iihs/topics/t/general-statistics/fatalityfacts/state-by-state-overview|title=General statistics|work=IIHS|access-date=2018-05-10}}</ref>, and in homes and communities.
== History == In 1996, the [[National Safety Council]] established June as National Safety Month, aiming to increase awareness of the leading safety and health risks and ultimately decrease the number of unintentional injuries and deaths in the United States. [[File:NSM Wrigley Building.png|thumb|Wrigley Building in Chicago lit up green for National Safety Month in 2017]] [https://facilityexecutive.com/2017/05/chicago-skyline-turning-green-for-national-safety-month/ In 2017]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://facilityexecutive.com/2017/05/chicago-skyline-turning-green-for-national-safety-month/|title=Chicago Skyline Turning Green For National Safety Month|last=McCandless|first=Mary Ellen|date=2017-05-30|work=Facility Executive - Creating Intelligent Buildings|access-date=2018-05-10|language=en-US}}</ref>, several buildings in the city of Chicago lit their building lights green to show their support for National Safety Month.
== National Safety Month 2018 == The theme for National Safety Month in June 2018 is "[https://www.nsc.org/work-safety/get-involved/national-safety-month No 1 Gets Hurt]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nsc.org/work-safety/get-involved/national-safety-month|title=National Safety Month|website=www.nsc.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-10}}</ref>." Each week in June correlates with a different safety topic:
=== Week 1 - Emergency Preparedness === Federal agencies, like [[United States Department of Homeland Security|Ready.gov]], the [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] and the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]], provide resources for emergency preparedness. Some 10,000 cardiac arrests occur each year in the workplace. Only 45% of American workers have had first aid training and only 50 percent know where to locate an automated external defibrillator.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.safetyandhealthmagazine.com/articles/15886-more-than-half-of-workers-arent-trained-on-first-aid-cpr-survey|title=More than half of workers arenât trained on first aid, CPR: survey|access-date=2018-05-10|language=en}}</ref>
=== Week 2 - Wellness === The [[Institute Of Medicine|Institute of Medicine]] estimates that 50-70 million Americans chronically suffer from a sleep disorder. For an individual, sleep disorders can have a substantial impact in reducing quality of life, increasing the risk of other health problems such as heart disease and diabetes, and even reducing lifespan.
=== Week 3 - Falls === Falls are the leading cause of injury-related death for adults age 65 and older<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/HomeandRecreationalSafety/Falls/adultfalls.html|title=Important Facts about Falls {{!}} Home and Recreational Safety {{!}} CDC Injury Center|date=2018-03-12|website=www.cdc.gov|language=en-us|access-date=2018-05-10}}</ref>. Falls are also the leading cause of death in construction according to [[Occupational Safety and Health Administration|OSHA]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.osha.gov/stopfalls/|title=OSHA's Fall Prevention Campaign {{!}} Occupational Safety and Health Administration|website=www.osha.gov|language=en-us|access-date=2018-05-10}}</ref>.
=== Week 4 - Driving === Drowsy driving contributes to about 10 percent of all motor vehicle-related crashes, exceeding federal estimates by nearly eightfold, according to newly released research from the AAA Foundation for Traffic Safety.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Treffers|first=R.|last2=Kubelka|first2=J.|last3=Fell|first3=J.C.|last4=Smith|first4=Ryan C.|last5=Turturici|first5=Marissa|date=2018-02-08|title=Prevalence of Drowsy Driving Crashes: Estimates from a Large-Scale Naturalistic Driving Study|url=http://aaafoundation.org/prevalence-drowsy-driving-crashes-estimates-large-scale-naturalistic-driving-study/|journal=AAA Foundation for Traffic Safety.|language=en-US}}</ref>
== National Safety Month 2017 == The theme for National Safety Month in June 2017 was "Keep Each Other Safe," which underscored the role every individual plays in the effort to eliminate preventable deaths. Each week in June correlated with a different safety topic:
=== Week 1 - Stand up to Falls === One in three older adults falls each year. About 2.5 million nonfatal falls were treated in emergency departments in 2013<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/HomeandRecreationalSafety/Falls/adultfalls.html|title=Important Facts about Falls {{!}} Home and Recreational Safety {{!}} CDC Injury Center|date=2018-03-12|website=www.cdc.gov|language=en-us|access-date=2018-05-10}}</ref>.
=== Week 2 - Recharge to be in Charge === More than 70 million Americans suffer from sleep problems, according to research from the [[National Institutes of Health]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/about/scientific-divisions/national-center-sleep-disorders-research|title=National Center on Sleep Disorders Research {{!}} National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI)|website=www.nhlbi.nih.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-05-10}}</ref>. Sleep disorders, like [[sleep apnea]], can be serious enough to interfere with an employee's well-being. Approximately 13% of work injuries could be attributed to sleep problems<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Uehli|first=Katrin|last2=Mehta|first2=Amar J.|last3=Miedinger|first3=David|last4=Hug|first4=Kerstin|last5=Schindler|first5=Christian|last6=Holsboer-Trachsler|first6=Edith|last7=Leuppi|first7=JÃ¶rg D.|last8=KÃ¼nzli|first8=Nino|date=2014-02|title=Sleep problems and work injuries: A systematic review and meta-analysis|url=https://www.smrv-journal.com/article/S1087-0792(13)00008-7/fulltext|journal=Sleep Medicine Reviews|language=English|volume=18|issue=1|pages=61â73|doi=10.1016/j.smrv.2013.01.004|issn=1087-0792}}</ref>.
=== Week 3 - Prepare for Active Shooters === An average of 70 people were wounded and 46 killed per year in active shooter events between 2014 and 2015<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://injuryfacts.nsc.org/home-and-community/safety-topics/firearms/|title=Firearms â Injury Facts|website=injuryfacts.nsc.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-10}}</ref>.
=== Week 4 - Don't just sit there === Overexertion continues to be a leading cause of injury over all age groups. It was the second leading reason that adults age 25-64 ended up in emergency departments in 2013, and the third leading cause for kids ages 10 and older, often from too-heavy backpacks, computers and gaming, and poor posture.
== Light Your City's Skyline Green == [[File:USG Building NSM.jpg|thumb|USG building of Chicago lit green for National Safety Month 2017]] In 2017, the [[Building Owners and Managers Association]] of Chicago (BOMA) approved the Council's lighting request, and [[Blue Cross Blue Shield Tower|Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Illinois]] building, [[Prudential Headquarters|Prudential Plaza]] and [[Wrigley Building|The Wrigley Building]], 400-410 North Michigan Ave., Chicago, Ill., were lit green in June to show support for National Safety Month. The buildings participate in the BOMA Building Lighting Partner Program â an initiative to light up the skyline for various civic and philanthropic causes.
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Month-long observances]] [[Category:June observances]] [[Category:Observances in the United States]] [[Category:Safety in the United States]]
